						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Greenland</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">

       </tr><tr style="font-size:xx-small;">
         <td align="right"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lower&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lower (page does not exist)">Template:Lower</a></td>
         <td colspan="2" style="padding-left:0;"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_aaa"><b><a href="#ref_aaa">^</a></b></span>  Greenlandic has been the sole official language of Greenland since 2009.<big><sup id="cite_ref-selvstyre_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-selvstyre-1">[1]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-law_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-law-5">[5]</a></sup></big></td>
       </tr><tr style="font-size:xx-small;" class="mergedrow">
         <td align="right"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lower&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lower (page does not exist)">Template:Lower</a></td>
         <td colspan="2" style="padding-left:0;"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_bbb"><b><a href="#ref_bbb">^</a></b></span>  Danish monarchy reached Greenland in 1380 with the reign of <a href="/wiki/Olaf_II_of_Denmark" title="Olaf II of Denmark">Olav IV</a> in Norway.</td>
       </tr><tr style="font-size:xx-small;" class="mergedrow">
         <td align="right"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lower&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lower (page does not exist)">Template:Lower</a></td>
         <td colspan="2" style="padding-left:0;"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_ccc"><b><a href="#ref_ccc">^</a></b></span>  Although previously under Danish monarchy for four hundred years, Greenland, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Faroe_Islands&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Faroe Islands (page does not exist)">Faroe Islands</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">Iceland</a> were formally Norwegian possessions until 1814.</td>
       </tr><tr style="font-size:xx-small;" class="mergedbottomrow">
         <td align="right"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lower&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lower (page does not exist)">Template:Lower</a></td>
         <td colspan="2" style="padding-left:0;"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_ddd"><b><a href="#ref_ddd">^</a></b></span> As of 2000:<br /><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> ice-free;<br /><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> ice-covered.<br />Density: 0.14/km<sup>2</sup> (0.36 /sq.&#160;mi) for ice-free areas.</td>
       </tr></table>
<p><b>Greenland</b> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-kl&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-kl (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-kl</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPA-kl&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPA-kl (page does not exist)">Template:IPA-kl</a>) is an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Autonomous_area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Autonomous area (page does not exist)">autonomous</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Constituent_country&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Constituent country (page does not exist)">country</a> within the <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">Kingdom of Denmark</a>, located between the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Arctic_Ocean&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Arctic Ocean (page does not exist)">Arctic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Oceans</a>, east of the <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Arctic_Archipelago" title="Canadian Arctic Archipelago">Canadian Arctic Archipelago</a>. Though <a href="/wiki/Physical_geography" title="Physical geography">physiographically</a> a part of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Continent&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Continent (page does not exist)">continent</a> of <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">North America</a>, Greenland has been politically and culturally associated with <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a> (specifically <a href="/wiki/Norway" title="Norway">Norway</a> and later Denmark) for more than a millennium.<sup id="cite_ref-Brown2000_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brown2000-6">[6]</a></sup> In 2008, the people of Greenland passed a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Greenlandic_self-government_referendum,_2008&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Greenlandic self-government referendum, 2008 (page does not exist)">referendum supporting greater autonomy</a>; 75% of votes cast were in favour. Greenland is, in terms of area, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_by_area" title="List of islands by area">world's largest island</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-jc_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jc-7">[7]</a></sup> over three-quarters of which is covered by the only contemporary <a href="/wiki/Greenland_ice_sheet" title="Greenland ice sheet">ice sheet</a> outside of Antarctica. With a population of 56,370<sup id="cite_ref-Greenland_in_Figures_2013_3-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Greenland_in_Figures_2013-3">[3]</a></sup> (2013), it is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependent_territories_by_population_density" title="List of sovereign states and dependent territories by population density">least densely populated country</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-popden_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-popden-8">[8]</a></sup>
</p><p>Greenland has been inhabited off and on for at least the last 4,500 years by Arctic peoples whose forebears migrated there from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Canada&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Canada (page does not exist)">Canada</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-natmus_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natmus-9">[9]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Norsemen" title="Norsemen" class="mw-redirect">Norsemen</a> settled on the uninhabited southern part of Greenland beginning in the 10th century. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Inuit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Inuit (page does not exist)">Inuit</a> peoples arrived in the 13th century. The Norse colonies disappeared in the late 15th&#160;century. In the early 18th century, <a href="/wiki/Scandinavia" title="Scandinavia">Scandinavia</a> and Greenland came back into contact with each other, and Denmark established sovereignty over the island.
</p><p>Having been ruled by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Denmark%E2%80%93Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Denmark–Norway (page does not exist)">Denmark–Norway</a> for centuries, Greenland (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-da&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-da (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-da</a>) became a <a href="/wiki/Danish_colonial_empire" title="Danish colonial empire">Danish colony</a> in 1814, and a part of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_Realm&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish Realm (page does not exist)">Danish Realm</a> in 1953 under the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Denmark" title="Constitution of Denmark">Constitution of Denmark</a>. In 1973, Greenland joined the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">European Economic Community</a> with <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">Denmark</a>. However, in a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Greenlandic_European_Economic_Community_membership_referendum,_1982&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Greenlandic European Economic Community membership referendum, 1982 (page does not exist)">referendum</a> in 1983, a majority of the population voted for Greenland to withdraw from the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">EEC</a>, and Greenland officially withdrew in 1985. In 1979, Denmark granted <a href="/wiki/Home_rule" title="Home rule">home rule</a> to Greenland, and in 2008, Greenlanders voted in favour of the Self-Government Act which transferred more power from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Government_of_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Government of Denmark (page does not exist)">Danish royal government</a> to the local <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Greenland" title="Politics of Greenland">Greenlandic</a> government. Under the new structure, in effect since 21 June 2009,<sup id="cite_ref-Greenland_In_Figures_2012_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Greenland_In_Figures_2012-10">[10]</a></sup> Greenland can gradually assume responsibility for policing, judicial system, company law, accounting and auditing; mineral resource activities; aviation; law of legal capacity, family law and succession law; aliens and border controls; the working environment; and financial regulation and supervision. The Danish government retains control of foreign affairs and national defence. It also retains control of monetary policy, providing an initial annual subsidy of <a href="/wiki/Danish_krone" title="Danish krone">DKK</a> 3.4&#160;billion, slated to diminish gradually over time as Greenland's economy is strengthened by increased income from the extraction of natural resources.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

</li>

</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<p>It was the early Scandinavian settlers who gave the country the name <i>Greenland.</i> In the <a href="/wiki/Sagas_of_Icelanders" title="Sagas of Icelanders">Icelandic sagas</a>, it is said that the Norwegian-born Icelander <a href="/wiki/Erik_the_Red" title="Erik the Red">Erik the Red</a> was exiled from <a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">Iceland</a> for murder. Along with his extended family and his <a href="/wiki/Thrall" title="Thrall">thralls</a>, he set out in ships to explore icy land known to lie to the northwest. After finding a habitable area and settling there, he named it <i><span lang="non"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Linktext&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Linktext (page does not exist)">Template:Linktext</a></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a></i> (translated as "Greenland"), supposedly in the hope that the pleasant name would attract settlers.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ancientstandard_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ancientstandard-12">[12]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
</p><p>The name of the country in <a href="/wiki/Greenlandic_language" title="Greenlandic language">Greenlandic</a> (Kalaallisut) is <span lang="kl"><i>Kalaallit Nunaat</i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> ("land of the Kalaallit").<sup id="cite_ref-InuitDictionary_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-InuitDictionary-14">[14]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Kalaallit" title="Kalaallit">Kalaallit</a> are the <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples" title="Indigenous peoples">indigenous</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Greenlandic_Inuit_people&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Greenlandic Inuit people (page does not exist)">Greenlandic Inuit people</a> who inhabit the country's western region.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Arctic_cultures_900-1500.png" title="File:Arctic cultures 900-1500.png">File:Arctic cultures 900-1500.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"></div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_Paleo-Eskimo_cultures">Early Paleo-Eskimo cultures</span></h3>
<p>In <a href="/w/index.php?title=Prehistory&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Prehistory (page does not exist)">prehistoric times</a>, Greenland was home to several successive <a href="/wiki/Paleo-Eskimo" title="Paleo-Eskimo">Paleo-Eskimo</a> cultures known primarily through archaeological finds. The earliest entry of the Paleo-Eskimo into Greenland is thought to have occurred about 2500&#160;BC. From around 2500&#160;BC to 800&#160;BC, southern and western Greenland was inhabited by the <a href="/wiki/Saqqaq_culture" title="Saqqaq culture">Saqqaq culture</a>. Most finds of Saqqaq-period archaeological remains have been around <a href="/w/index.php?title=Disko_Bay&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Disko Bay (page does not exist)">Disko Bay</a>. From 2400&#160;BC to 1300&#160;BC, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Independence_I_culture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Independence I culture (page does not exist)">Independence I culture</a> existed in northern Greenland. It was a part of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Arctic_small_tool_tradition&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Arctic small tool tradition (page does not exist)">Arctic small tool tradition</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Greenland_History_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Greenland_History-15">[15]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Greenland_Migration_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Greenland_Migration-16">[16]</a></sup> Towns, including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Deltaterrasserne&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Deltaterrasserne (page does not exist)">Deltaterrasserne</a>, started to appear.
</p><p>Around 800&#160;BC, the Saqqaq culture disappeared and the Early <a href="/wiki/Dorset_culture" title="Dorset culture">Dorset culture</a> emerged in western Greenland and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Independence_II_culture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Independence II culture (page does not exist)">Independence II culture</a> in northern Greenland. The Dorset culture was the first culture to extend throughout the Greenlandic coastal areas, both on the west and east coasts, and it lasted until the total onset of the <a href="/wiki/Thule_people" title="Thule people">Thule culture</a> in 1500&#160;AD. The Dorset culture population lived primarily from <a href="/wiki/Aboriginal_whaling" title="Aboriginal whaling">whale hunting</a>. The Thule culture people are the ancestors of the current Greenlandic population. They started migrating from <a href="/wiki/Alaska" title="Alaska">Alaska</a> around 1000&#160;AD, reaching Greenland around 1300&#160;AD. The Thule culture was the first to introduce to Greenland such technological innovations as <a href="/wiki/Dog_sled" title="Dog sled">dog sleds</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Toggling_harpoon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Toggling harpoon (page does not exist)">toggling harpoons</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Norse_settlement">Norse settlement</span></h3>
<p>From 986&#160;AD, Greenland's west coast was settled by <a href="/wiki/Icelanders" title="Icelanders">Icelanders</a> and <a href="/wiki/Norwegians" title="Norwegians">Norwegians</a> in two settlements on <a href="/wiki/Fjord" title="Fjord">fjords</a> near the southwestern-most tip of the island.<sup id="cite_ref-Brown2000_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brown2000-6">[6]</a></sup> They shared the island with the late Dorset culture inhabitants who occupied the northern and western parts, and later with the Thule culture arriving from the north. Norse Greenlanders submitted to Norwegian rule in the 13th century, and the kingdom of Norway entered into a personal union with <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">Denmark</a> in 1380, and from 1397 was a part of the <a href="/wiki/Kalmar_Union" title="Kalmar Union">Kalmar Union</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
</p><p>The settlements, such as <a href="/wiki/Brattahl%C3%AD%C3%B0" title="Brattahlíð">Brattahlíð</a>, thrived for centuries but disappeared sometime in the 15th century, perhaps at the onset of the <a href="/wiki/Little_Ice_Age" title="Little Ice Age">Little Ice Age</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Diamond_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Diamond-18">[18]</a></sup>
Apart from some runic inscriptions, no contemporary records or historiography survives from the Norse settlements. Icelandic saga accounts of life in Greenland were composed in the thirteenth century and later, and do not constitute primary sources for the history of early Greenland.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> Modern understanding therefore depends on the physical data. Interpretation of <a href="/wiki/Ice_core" title="Ice core">ice core</a> and <a href="/wiki/Clam" title="Clam">clam</a> shell data suggests that between 800 and 1300&#160;AD, the regions around the fjords of southern Greenland experienced a relatively mild climate several degrees Celsius higher than usual in the North Atlantic,<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup> with trees and <a href="/wiki/Herbaceous_plant" title="Herbaceous plant">herbaceous plants</a> growing and livestock being farmed. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Barley&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Barley (page does not exist)">Barley</a> was grown as a crop up to the 70th&#160;parallel.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup> What is verifiable is that the ice cores indicate Greenland has experienced dramatic temperature shifts many times over the past 100,000 years.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> Similarly the <a href="/wiki/Landn%C3%A1mab%C3%B3k" title="Landnámabók">Icelandic Book of Settlements</a> records <a href="/wiki/Famine" title="Famine">famines</a> during the winters in which "the old and helpless were killed and thrown over cliffs". (Arnold 2010)
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Hvalsey.jpg" title="File:Hvalsey.jpg">File:Hvalsey.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The last written records of the <a href="/wiki/Norsemen" title="Norsemen" class="mw-redirect">Norse</a> Greenlanders are of a marriage in 1408 in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Church_of_Hvalsey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Church of Hvalsey (page does not exist)">church of Hvalsey</a>—today the best-preserved Nordic ruins in Greenland.</div></div></div>
<p>These <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norse_colonization_of_Greenland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Norse colonization of Greenland (page does not exist)">Icelandic settlements</a> vanished during the 14th and 15th&#160;centuries, probably as a result of famine and increasing conflicts with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Inuit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Inuit (page does not exist)">Inuit</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> The condition of human bones from this period indicates that the Norse population was <a href="/wiki/Malnutrition" title="Malnutrition">malnourished</a>, probably due to <a href="/wiki/Erosion" title="Erosion">soil erosion</a> resulting from the Norsemen's destruction of natural vegetation in the course of farming, turf-cutting, and wood-cutting, <a href="/wiki/Pandemic" title="Pandemic">pandemic</a> <a href="/wiki/Infectious_disease" title="Infectious disease" class="mw-redirect">plague</a>, a decline in temperatures during the Little Ice Age, and armed conflicts with the Inuit.<sup id="cite_ref-Diamond_18-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Diamond-18">[18]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1500.E2.80.931814">1500–1814</span></h3>
<p>In 1500, King <a href="/wiki/Manuel_I_of_Portugal" title="Manuel I of Portugal">Manuel&#160;I of Portugal</a> sent <a href="/wiki/Gaspar_Corte-Real" title="Gaspar Corte-Real">Gaspar Corte-Real</a> to Greenland in search of a <a href="/wiki/Northwest_Passage" title="Northwest Passage">Northwest Passage</a> to Asia which, according to the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Tordesillas" title="Treaty of Tordesillas">Treaty of Tordesillas</a>, was part of the Portuguese area of influence. In 1501, Corte-Real returned with his brother, <a href="/wiki/Miguel_Corte-Real" title="Miguel Corte-Real">Miguel Corte-Real</a>. Finding the sea frozen, they headed south and arrived in <a href="/wiki/Labrador" title="Labrador">Labrador</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Newfoundland_(island)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Newfoundland (island) (page does not exist)">Newfoundland</a>. Upon the brothers' return to Portugal, the cartographic information supplied by Corte-Real was incorporated into a new map of the world which was presented to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ercole_I_d%27Este,_Duke_of_Ferrara&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ercole I d'Este, Duke of Ferrara (page does not exist)">Ercole I d'Este</a>, <a href="/wiki/Duke_of_Ferrara_and_of_Modena" title="Duke of Ferrara and of Modena">Duke of Ferrara</a>, by Alberto Cantino in 1502. The <a href="/wiki/Cantino_planisphere" title="Cantino planisphere"><i>Cantino</i> planisphere</a>, made in Lisbon, accurately depicts the southern coastline of Greenland.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1605–1607, King <a href="/wiki/Christian_IV_of_Denmark" title="Christian IV of Denmark">Christian IV of Denmark</a> sent a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Christian_IV%27s_expeditions_to_Greenland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Christian IV's expeditions to Greenland (page does not exist)">series of expeditions</a> to Greenland and Arctic waterways to locate the lost eastern Norse settlement and assert Danish sovereignty over Greenland. The expeditions were mostly unsuccessful, partly due to leaders who lacked experience with the difficult arctic ice and weather conditions, and partly because the expedition leaders were given instructions to search for the Eastern Settlement on the east coast of Greenland just north of <a href="/wiki/Cape_Farewell,_Greenland" title="Cape Farewell, Greenland">Cape Farewell</a>, which is almost inaccessible due to southward <a href="/wiki/Drift_ice" title="Drift ice">drifting ice</a>. The pilot on all three trips was English explorer <a href="/w/index.php?title=James_Hall_(explorer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="James Hall (explorer) (page does not exist)">James Hall</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Old_Greenland_1747.jpg" title="File:Old Greenland 1747.jpg">File:Old Greenland 1747.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A 1747 map based on Egede's descriptions and misconceptions.</div></div></div>
<p>After the Norse settlements died off, the area came under the de&#160;facto control of various Inuit groups, but the Danish government never forgot or relinquished the claims to Greenland that it had inherited from the Norwegians; and when contact with Greenland was re-established in the early 18th&#160;century, Denmark asserted its sovereignty over the island. In 1721, a joint mercantile and clerical expedition led by Danish-Norwegian missionary <a href="/wiki/Hans_Egede" title="Hans Egede">Hans Egede</a> was sent to Greenland, not knowing whether a Norse civilization remained there. The expedition can be seen as part of the <a href="/wiki/Danish_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="Danish colonization of the Americas">Danish colonization of the Americas</a>. After 15&#160;years in Greenland, Hans Egede left his son <a href="/wiki/Paul_Egede" title="Paul Egede">Paul Egede</a> in charge of the mission in Greenland and returned to Denmark where he established a Greenland Seminary. This new colony was centred at <a href="/wiki/Nuuk" title="Nuuk">Godthåb</a> ("Good Hope") on the southwest coast. Gradually, Greenland was opened up to Danish merchants, and closed to those from other countries.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Treaty_of_Kiel_to_World_War_II">Treaty of Kiel to World War II</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:EricTheRedsLand.gif" title="File:EricTheRedsLand.gif">File:EricTheRedsLand.gif</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Eirik Raudes Land</div></div></div>
<p>When the union between the crowns of Denmark and Norway was dissolved in 1814, the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Kiel" title="Treaty of Kiel">Treaty of Kiel</a> severed Norway's former colonies and left them under the control of the Danish monarch.
</p><p>Norway occupied then-uninhabited eastern Greenland as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Erik_the_Red%27s_Land&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Erik the Red's Land (page does not exist)">Erik the Red's Land</a> in July 1931, claiming that it constituted <i><a href="/wiki/Terra_nullius" title="Terra nullius">terra nullius</a></i>. Norway and Denmark agreed to submit the matter in 1933 to the <a href="/wiki/Permanent_Court_of_International_Justice" title="Permanent Court of International Justice">Permanent Court of International Justice</a>, which decided against Norway.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup>
</p><p>Greenland's connection to Denmark was severed on 9 April 1940, early in <a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_Greenland_during_World_War_II&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="History of Greenland during World War II (page does not exist)">World War&#160;II</a>, when Denmark was occupied by <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a>. On 8 April 1941, the United States occupied Greenland to defend it against a possible invasion by Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> The United States occupation of Greenland continued until 1945. Greenland was able to buy goods from the United States and Canada by selling <a href="/wiki/Cryolite" title="Cryolite">cryolite</a> from the mine at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ivittuut&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ivittuut (page does not exist)">Ivittuut</a>. The major air bases were <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bluie_West-1&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bluie West-1 (page does not exist)">Bluie West-1</a> at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Narsarsuaq_Airport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Narsarsuaq Airport (page does not exist)">Narsarsuaq</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bluie_West-8&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bluie West-8 (page does not exist)">Bluie West-8</a> at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kangerlussuaq_Airport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kangerlussuaq Airport (page does not exist)">Søndre Strømfjord</a> (Kangerlussuaq), both of which are still used as Greenland's major international airports. During this war, the system of government changed: <a href="/wiki/List_of_governors_of_Greenland" title="List of governors of Greenland">Governor</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eske_Brun&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eske Brun (page does not exist)">Eske Brun</a> ruled the island under a law of 1925 that allowed governors to take control under extreme circumstances; Governor Aksel Svane was transferred to the United States to lead the commission to supply Greenland. The Danish <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sl%C3%A6depatruljen_Sirius&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Slædepatruljen Sirius (page does not exist)">Sirius Patrol</a> guarded the northeastern shores of Greenland in 1942 using dogsleds, detecting several German <a href="/wiki/Weather_station" title="Weather station">weather stations</a> and alerting American troops who then destroyed them. After the collapse of the Third Reich, <a href="/wiki/Albert_Speer" title="Albert Speer">Albert Speer</a> briefly considered escaping in a small aeroplane to hide out in Greenland, but changed his mind and decided to turn himself in to the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces" title="United States Armed Forces">United States Armed Forces</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup>
</p><p>Greenland had been a protected and very isolated society until 1940. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Politics_of_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Politics of Denmark (page does not exist)">Danish government</a> had maintained a strict monopoly of <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Greenland" title="Economy of Greenland">Greenlandic trade</a>, allowing only small scale <a href="/w/index.php?title=Troaking&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Troaking (page does not exist)">troaking</a> with Scottish whalers. Nevertheless, wartime Greenland developed a sense of self-reliance through self-government and independent communication with the outside world. Despite this change, in 1946 a commission including the highest Greenlandic council, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Landsr%C3%A5dene&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Landsrådene (page does not exist)">Landsrådene</a>, recommended patience and no radical reform of the system. Two years later, the first step towards a change of government was initiated when a grand commission was established. A final report (G-50) was presented in 1950: Greenland was to be a modern <a href="/wiki/Welfare_state" title="Welfare state">welfare state</a> with Denmark as sponsor and example. In 1953 Greenland was made an equal part of the Danish Kingdom. Home rule was granted in 1979.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Home_rule_and_self-rule">Home rule and self-rule</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ilimmarfik.jpg" title="File:Ilimmarfik.jpg">File:Ilimmarfik.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The orthography and vocabulary of the Greenlandic language is governed by <i>Oqaasileriffik</i>, the Greenlandic language secretariat, located in the <i>Ilimmarfik</i> university Campus in <a href="/wiki/Nuuk" title="Nuuk">Nuuk</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Following World War II, the United States developed a <a href="/wiki/Geopolitics" title="Geopolitics">geopolitical</a> interest in Greenland, and in 1946 the United States offered to buy Greenland from Denmark for $100,000,000, but Denmark refused to sell.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> However, in 1950, Denmark did agree to allow the United States to reestablish <a href="/wiki/Thule_Air_Base" title="Thule Air Base">Thule Air Base</a>, which was greatly expanded between 1951 and 1953 as part of a unified <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a> defence strategy. The local population of three nearby villages was moved over 100&#160;kilometres (62&#160;mi) away in the winter. A secret attempt to construct a subterranean network of nuclear missile launch sites in the Greenlandic ice cap named <a href="/w/index.php?title=Project_Iceworm&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Project Iceworm (page does not exist)">Project Iceworm</a> was carried out from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Camp_Century&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Camp Century (page does not exist)">Camp Century</a> from 1960 to 1966 before being abandoned as unworkable. The Danish government did not become aware of the programme's actual mission until 1997, when it was discovered while looking for records related to the crash of a nuclear-equipped <a href="/w/index.php?title=B-52&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="B-52 (page does not exist)">B-52</a>&#160;bomber at Thule in 1968.
</p><p>With the 1953 Danish constitution, Greenland's colonial status ended as the island was incorporated into the Danish realm as an <a href="/wiki/Amt_(country_subdivision)" title="Amt (country subdivision)">amt</a> (county), also extending Danish citizenship to Greenlanders. This also resulted in a change in Danish policies toward Greenland that consisted of a strategy of cultural assimilation—or de-Greenlandification. During this period, the Danish government promoted the exclusive use of Danish in official matters, and required Greenlanders to go to Denmark for their post-secondary education; many Greenlandic children grew up in boarding schools in southern Denmark, many losing their cultural ties to Greenland. While the policies "succeeded" in the sense of creating a demographic shift turning Greenlanders from being primarily subsistence hunters into being urbanized wage earners, the policy also backfired to produce a reassertion of Greenlandic cultural identity by the Greenlandic elite, leading to a movement in favour of independence that reached its peak in the 1970s.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup> As a consequence of political complications in relation to Denmark's entry into the European Common Market in 1972, a further desire to establish the legality of Greenland's status formed in Denmark, resulting in the Home Rule Act of 1979, which gave Greenland limited autonomy with <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Greenland" title="Parliament of Greenland">its own legislature</a> taking control of some internal policies, while the <a href="/wiki/Folketing" title="Folketing">Parliament of Denmark</a> maintained full control of external policies, security, and natural resources. The law came into effect on 1 May 1979. The <a href="/wiki/List_of_Danish_monarchs" title="List of Danish monarchs">Queen of Denmark</a>, <a href="/wiki/Margrethe_II_of_Denmark" title="Margrethe II of Denmark">Margrethe&#160;II</a>, remains Greenland's <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">Head of state</a>. In 1985, Greenland left the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">European Economic Community</a> (EEC) upon achieving self-rule, in view of the EEC's commercial fishing regulations and an EEC ban on <a href="/wiki/Pinniped" title="Pinniped">seal</a> skin products.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup> A <a href="/w/index.php?title=Greenlandic_self-government_referendum,_2008&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Greenlandic self-government referendum, 2008 (page does not exist)">referendum on greater autonomy</a> was approved on 25 November 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 21 June 2009, Greenland assumed self-determination with responsibility for self-government of <a href="/wiki/Judiciary" title="Judiciary">judicial affairs</a>, policing, and <a href="/wiki/Natural_resource" title="Natural resource">natural resources</a>. Also, Greenlanders were recognized as a separate people under <a href="/w/index.php?title=International_law&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="International law (page does not exist)">international law</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup> Denmark maintains control of <a href="/wiki/Foreign_policy" title="Foreign policy">foreign affairs</a> and <a href="/wiki/Military" title="Military">defence</a> matters. Denmark upholds the annual block grant of 3.2&#160;billion Danish kroner, but as Greenland begins to collect revenues of its natural resources, the grant will gradually be diminished. It is considered by some to be a step toward eventual full independence from Denmark.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Greenlandic_language" title="Greenlandic language">Greenlandic</a> became the sole official language of Greenland at the historic ceremony.<sup id="cite_ref-selvstyre_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-selvstyre-1">[1]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-law_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-law-5">[5]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government">Government</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Greenland's <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a> is <a href="/wiki/Margrethe_II_of_Denmark" title="Margrethe II of Denmark">Margrethe&#160;II</a>, <a href="/wiki/Queen_regnant" title="Queen regnant">Queen regnant</a> of <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">Denmark</a>. The Queen's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Politics_of_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Politics of Denmark (page does not exist)">government in Denmark</a> appoints a <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_Danish_High_Commissioners_in_Greenland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of Danish High Commissioners in Greenland (page does not exist)">High Commissioner</a> (<i>Rigsombudsmand</i>) to represent it on the island. The current commissioner is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mikaela_Engell&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mikaela Engell (page does not exist)">Mikaela Engell</a>.
</p><p>Greenlanders elect two representatives to the <a href="/wiki/Folketing" title="Folketing">Folketing</a>, Denmark's parliament, out of 179 total. The current representatives are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sara_Olsvig&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sara Olsvig (page does not exist)">Sara Olsvig</a> of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Inuit_Community&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Inuit Community (page does not exist)">Inuit Community</a> Party and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Doris_Jakobsen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Doris Jakobsen (page does not exist)">Doris Jakobsen</a> from the Siumut Party from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Forward_(Greenland)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Forward (Greenland) (page does not exist)">Forward</a> Party.
</p><p>Greenland also has its own <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Greenland" title="Parliament of Greenland">Parliament</a>, which has 31&#160;members. The government is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Naalakkersuisut&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Naalakkersuisut (page does not exist)">Naalakkersuisut</a> whose members are appointed by the Prime Minister. The <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a> is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Prime_Ministers_of_Greenland" title="List of Prime Ministers of Greenland" class="mw-redirect">Prime Minister</a>, usually the leader of the majority party in Parliament. The current Prime Minister is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aleqa_Hammond&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aleqa Hammond (page does not exist)">Aleqa Hammond</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Siumut" title="Siumut">Siumut</a> Party.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Greenland-municipalities-2009.svg" title="File:Greenland-municipalities-2009.svg">File:Greenland-municipalities-2009.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Municipalities of Greenland</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Although it is largely unpopulated, Greenland abolished its three counties in 2009 and has since been divided into four territories known as "municipalities": <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sermersooq&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sermersooq (page does not exist)">Sermersooq</a> ("Much Ice") around the capital <a href="/wiki/Nuuk" title="Nuuk">Nuuk</a>; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kujalleq&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kujalleq (page does not exist)">Kujalleq</a> ("South") around <a href="/wiki/Cape_Farewell,_Greenland" title="Cape Farewell, Greenland">Cape Farewell</a>; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Qeqqata&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Qeqqata (page does not exist)">Qeqqata</a> ("Centre") north of the capital along the <a href="/wiki/Davis_Strait" title="Davis Strait">Davis Strait</a>; and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Qaasuitsup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Qaasuitsup (page does not exist)">Qaasuitsup</a> ("Darkness") in the northwest. The northeast of the island composes the unincorporated <a href="/w/index.php?title=Northeast_Greenland_National_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Northeast Greenland National Park (page does not exist)">Northeast Greenland National Park</a>. <a href="/wiki/Thule_Air_Base" title="Thule Air Base">Thule Air Base</a> is also unincorporated, an enclave within Qaaquitsup municipality administered by the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Air_Force" title="United States Air Force">United States Air Force</a>. During its construction, there were as many as 12,000 American residents but in recent years the number is below 1,000.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>The party system is currently dominated by the social democratic <a href="/w/index.php?title=Forward_(Greenland)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Forward (Greenland) (page does not exist)">Forward</a> Party (14&#160;MPs), and the democratic socialist <a href="/w/index.php?title=Inuit_Community&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Inuit Community (page does not exist)">Inuit Community</a> Party (11&#160;MPs), both of which broadly argue for greater independence from Denmark. While the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Greenlandic_parliamentary_election,_2009&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Greenlandic parliamentary election, 2009 (page does not exist)">2009 election</a> saw the unionist—and largely Danish—<a href="/wiki/Democrats_(Greenland)" title="Democrats (Greenland)">Democrat</a> Party (2&#160;MPs) decline greatly, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Greenlandic_parliamentary_election,_2013&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Greenlandic parliamentary election, 2013 (page does not exist)">2013 election</a> consolidated the power of the two main parties at the expense of the smaller groups, and saw the far-left <a href="/w/index.php?title=Inuit_Party&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Inuit Party (page does not exist)">Inuit Party</a> (2&#160;MPs) elected to the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Greenland" title="Parliament of Greenland">Parliament</a> for the first time.
</p><p>The non-binding <a href="/w/index.php?title=Greenlandic_self-government_referendum,_2008&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Greenlandic self-government referendum, 2008 (page does not exist)">2008 referendum on self-governance</a> favoured increased self-governance 21,355 votes to 6,663.
</p><p>In 1985, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Greenland%E2%80%93European_Union_relations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Greenland–European Union relations (page does not exist)">Greenland left the European Economic Community</a> (EEC), unlike Denmark, which remains a member. The EEC later became the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> (EU, it was renamed and expanded in scope in 1992). Greenland retains some ties with the EU via Denmark. However, EU law largely does not apply to Greenland except in the area of trade.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Economics_and_business">Economics and business</span></h3>
<p>{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Unreferenced section |date=__DATE__ |$B=
{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Unreferenced |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Ambox&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Ambox (page does not exist)">Template:Ambox</a>
}}
}}
About half of public spending on Greenland is funded by block grants from Denmark which in 2007 totalled over 3.2&#160;billion kr. Additional proceeds from the sale of fishing licences and the annual compensation from the EU represents 280&#160;million DKK per year. Greenland's economy is based on a narrow professional basis with the fishing industry as the dominant sector with some 90% of its exports. In a few years, quarrying and tourism could complement the fisheries that depend on the changing prices of fish and fishing opportunities. The long-range divides the domestic market into many small units that have high operating costs. Most of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fish_factory&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fish factory (page does not exist)">fish factories</a> are owned by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Royal_Greenland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Royal Greenland (page does not exist)">Royal Greenland</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography_and_climate">Geography and climate</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Greenland_ice_sheet_AMSL_thickness_map-en.png" title="File:Greenland ice sheet AMSL thickness map-en.png">File:Greenland ice sheet AMSL thickness map-en.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Map of Greenland.</div></div></div>
<p>Greenland lies between latitudes <a href="/w/index.php?title=59th_parallel_north&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="59th parallel north (page does not exist)">59°</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=83rd_parallel_north&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="83rd parallel north (page does not exist)">83°N</a>, and longitudes <a href="/w/index.php?title=11th_meridian_west&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="11th meridian west (page does not exist)">11°</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=74th_meridian_west&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="74th meridian west (page does not exist)">74°W</a> and is the third largest country in North America.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup>
The Atlantic Ocean borders Greenland's southeast; the <a href="/wiki/Greenland_Sea" title="Greenland Sea">Greenland Sea</a> is to the east; the Arctic Ocean is to the north; and <a href="/wiki/Baffin_Bay" title="Baffin Bay">Baffin Bay</a> is to the west. The nearest countries are Canada, to the west across Baffin Bay, and Iceland, east of Greenland in the Atlantic Ocean. Greenland also contains the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Northeast_Greenland_National_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Northeast Greenland National Park (page does not exist)">world's largest national park</a>, and is the world's largest island and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries and dependencies by area (page does not exist)">largest</a> <a href="/wiki/Dependent_territory" title="Dependent territory">dependent territory</a> by area in the world.
</p><p>The average daily temperature of Nuuk, Greenland varies over the seasons from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Greenland_eastcoast.jpg" title="File:Greenland eastcoast.jpg">File:Greenland eastcoast.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Southeast coast of Greenland.</div></div></div>
<p>The total area of Greenland is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> (including other offshore minor islands), of which the <a href="/wiki/Greenland_ice_sheet" title="Greenland ice sheet">Greenland ice sheet</a> covers <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> (81%) and has a volume of approximately <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> The highest point on Greenland is <a href="/wiki/Gunnbj%C3%B8rn_Fjeld" title="Gunnbjørn Fjeld">Gunnbjørn Fjeld</a> at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>. The majority of Greenland, however, is less than <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> in elevation.
</p><p>The weight of the ice sheet has depressed the central land area to form a basin lying more than <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> below sea level,<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Atlas_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Atlas-42">[42]</a></sup> while elevations rise suddenly and steeply near the coast.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup>
The ice <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ice-sheet_dynamics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ice-sheet dynamics (page does not exist)">flows</a> generally to the coast from the centre of the island. A survey led by French scientist <a href="/w/index.php?title=Paul-Emile_Victor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Paul-Emile Victor (page does not exist)">Paul-Emile Victor</a> in 1951 concluded that, under the ice sheet, Greenland is composed of three large islands.<sup id="cite_ref-ellensburg_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ellensburg-44">[44]</a></sup> This is disputed, but if it is so, they would be separated by narrow straits, reaching the sea at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ilulissat_Icefjord&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ilulissat Icefjord (page does not exist)">Ilulissat Icefjord</a>, at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Greenland%27s_Grand_Canyon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Greenland's Grand Canyon (page does not exist)">Greenland's Grand Canyon</a> and south of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nordostrundingen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nordostrundingen (page does not exist)">Nordostrundingen</a>.
</p><p>All <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Greenland" title="List of cities and towns in Greenland">towns and settlements of Greenland</a> are situated along the ice-free coast, with the population being concentrated along the west coast. The northeastern part of Greenland is not part of any municipality, but is the site of the world's largest national park, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Northeast_Greenland_National_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Northeast Greenland National Park (page does not exist)">Northeast Greenland National Park</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Greenlandmountains.jpg" title="File:Greenlandmountains.jpg">File:Greenlandmountains.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">View of mountains on Greenland from the air</div></div></div>
<p>At least four scientific expedition stations and camps had been established on the ice sheet in the ice-covered central part of Greenland (indicated as pale blue in the map to the right): <a href="/wiki/Eismitte" title="Eismitte">Eismitte</a>, <a href="/wiki/North_Ice" title="North Ice">North Ice</a>, North GRIP Camp and The Raven Skiway. Currently, there is a year-round station, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Summit_Camp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Summit Camp (page does not exist)">Summit Camp</a>, on the ice sheet, established in 1989. The radio station <a href="/w/index.php?title=J%C3%B8rgen_Br%C3%B8nlund_Fjord&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jørgen Brønlund Fjord (page does not exist)">Jørgen Brønlund Fjord</a> was, until 1950, the northernmost permanent outpost in the world.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Greenland_scenery.jpg" title="File:Greenland scenery.jpg">File:Greenland scenery.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Southern Greenland scenery, near <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nanortalik&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nanortalik (page does not exist)">Nanortalik</a>, where <a href="/wiki/Fjord" title="Fjord">fjords</a> and mountains dominate the landscape.</div></div></div>
<p>The extreme north of Greenland, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Peary_Land&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Peary Land (page does not exist)">Peary Land</a>, is not covered by an ice sheet, because the air there is too dry to produce snow, which is essential in the production and maintenance of an ice sheet. If the Greenland ice sheet were to <a href="/wiki/Melting" title="Melting">melt</a> away completely, the world's sea level would rise by more than <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Greenland2.1ac.jpg" title="File:Greenland2.1ac.jpg">File:Greenland2.1ac.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Scoresby_Sund" title="Scoresby Sund">Scoresby Sund</a> in eastern Greenland, the longest <a href="/wiki/Fjord" title="Fjord">fjord</a> in the world.</div></div></div>
<p>Between 1989 and 1993, US and European <a href="/wiki/Climate" title="Climate">climate</a> researchers drilled into the summit of Greenland's ice sheet, obtaining a pair of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> long <a href="/wiki/Ice_core" title="Ice core">ice cores</a>. Analysis of the layering and chemical composition of the cores has provided a revolutionary new record of climate change in the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Hemisphere" title="Northern Hemisphere">Northern Hemisphere</a> going back about 100,000&#160;years, and illustrated that the world's weather and temperature have often shifted rapidly from one seemingly stable state to another, with worldwide <a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">consequences</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup> The glaciers of Greenland are also contributing to a rise in the global sea level at a faster rate than was previously believed.<sup id="cite_ref-National_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-National-48">[48]</a></sup> Between 1991 and 2004, monitoring of the weather at one location (Swiss Camp) showed that the average winter temperature had risen almost <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> Other research has shown that higher snowfalls from the <a href="/wiki/North_Atlantic_oscillation" title="North Atlantic oscillation">North Atlantic oscillation</a> caused the interior of the ice cap to thicken by an average of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>/yr between 1994 and 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup>
</p>
However, a recent study suggests a much warmer planet in relatively recent <a href="/wiki/Geologic_time_scale" title="Geologic time scale">geological times</a>: <blockquote>Scientists who probed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> through a Greenland glacier to recover the some of the oldest plant&#160;<a href="/wiki/DNA" title="DNA">DNA</a> on record said that the planet was far warmer hundreds of thousands of years ago than is generally believed. DNA of trees, plants, and insects including <a href="/wiki/Butterfly" title="Butterfly">butterflies</a> and spiders from beneath the southern Greenland glacier was estimated to date to 450,000 to 900,000&#160;years ago, according to the remnants retrieved from this long-vanished boreal forest. That view contrasts sharply with the prevailing one that a lush forest of this kind could not have existed in Greenland any later than 2.4&#160;million years ago. These DNA samples suggest that the temperature probably reached <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> in the summer and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> in the winter. They also indicate that during the last <a href="/w/index.php?title=Interglacial&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Interglacial (page does not exist)">interglacial</a> period, 130,000–116,000&#160;years ago, when local temperatures were on average <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> higher than now, the glaciers on Greenland did not completely melt away.<sup id="cite_ref-pmid17615355_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pmid17615355-51">[51]</a></sup></blockquote>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Topographic_map_of_Greenland_bedrock.jpg" title="File:Topographic map of Greenland bedrock.jpg">File:Topographic map of Greenland bedrock.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Greenland bedrock, at current elevation above sea level</div></div></div>
<p>In 1996, the American Top of the World expedition found the world's northernmost island off Greenland: <a href="/w/index.php?title=ATOW1996&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="ATOW1996 (page does not exist)">ATOW1996</a>. An even more northerly candidate was spotted during the return from the expedition, but its status is yet to be confirmed.
</p><p>In 2007 the existence of a new island was announced. Named "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Uunartoq_Qeqertaq&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Uunartoq Qeqertaq (page does not exist)">Uunartoq Qeqertaq</a>" (English: <i>Warming Island</i>), this island has always been present off the coast of Greenland, but was covered by a glacier. This glacier was discovered in 2002 to be shrinking rapidly, and by 2007 had completely melted away, leaving the exposed island.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup> The island was named Place of the Year by the Oxford Atlas of the World in 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup> Ben Keene, the atlas's editor, commented: "In the last two or three decades, global warming has reduced the size of glaciers throughout the <a href="/wiki/Arctic" title="Arctic">Arctic</a> and earlier this year, news sources confirmed what climate scientists already knew: water, not rock, lay beneath this <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ice_bridge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ice bridge (page does not exist)">ice bridge</a> on the east coast of Greenland. More islets are likely to appear as the sheet of frozen water covering the world's largest island continues to melt".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cite_quote&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cite quote (page does not exist)">Template:Cite quote</a>
</p><p>Some controversy surrounds the history of the island, specifically over whether the island might have been revealed during a brief warm period in Greenland during the mid-20th&#160;century.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Postglacial_glacier_advances">Postglacial glacier advances</span></h3>
<p>{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Technical |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Ambox&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Ambox (page does not exist)">Template:Ambox</a>
}}
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Copyedit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Copyedit (page does not exist)">Template:Copyedit</a>
The Qaqugdluit mountainous area on the south side of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuussuaq_Peninsula&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuussuaq Peninsula (page does not exist)">Nuussuaq Peninsula</a> at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Coord&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Coord (page does not exist)">Template:Coord</a> shows Historical to <a href="/wiki/Holocene" title="Holocene">Holocene</a> Post-glacial glacier stages dating back at least 7,000 and at most 10,000 years.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-W1968_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-W1968-56">[56]</a></sup> In 1979 the glaciers ended between 660m and 140m (2,165 and 459&#160;ft) above sea level. The pertinent climatic glacier- snowline (ELA) ran at c. 800m (2,625&#160;ft) in height. The snowline of the oldest (VII) of the three Holocene glacier stages (V – VII) ran c. 230m (755&#160;ft) deeper, i.e. at c. 570m (1,870&#160;ft) in height.<sup id="cite_ref-K1983_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-K1983-57">[57]</a></sup> The four youngest glacier stages (IV-I) are of a Historical age. They have to be classified as belonging to the global glacier advances in the years 1811 to 1850 and 1880 to 1900 (“Little Ice Age”), 1910 to 1930, 1948 and 1953.<sup id="cite_ref-W1968_56-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-W1968-56">[56]</a></sup> Their snowlines rose step by step up to the level of 1979. The current snowline (Stage 0) runs nearly unchanged.
</p><p>During the oldest Postglacial Stage VII, an ice stream network completely covered the landscape as valley glaciers joined each other. Its nourishing areas consisted of high-lying plateau-glaciers and local ice caps. Due to the uplift of the snowline about that c. 230m (755&#160;ft) – what corresponds to a warming about c. 1.5°C (34.7°C) – since 1979 there merely exists a plateau- glaciation with small glacier tongues hanging down on the margins that nearly did not reach the main valley bottoms any more.<sup id="cite_ref-K1983_57-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-K1983-57">[57]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Nature">Nature</span></h3>
<p>{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Unreferenced section |date=__DATE__ |$B=
{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Unreferenced |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Ambox&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Ambox (page does not exist)">Template:Ambox</a>
}}
}}
The few land mammals in Greenland include <a href="/wiki/Polar_bear" title="Polar bear">polar bear</a>, <a href="/wiki/Reindeer" title="Reindeer">reindeer</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Musk_ox&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Musk ox (page does not exist)">musk ox</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arctic_fox" title="Arctic fox">arctic fox</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wolf&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wolf (page does not exist)">wolf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stoat" title="Stoat">stoat</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Arctic_hare" title="Arctic hare">arctic hare</a>. There are dozens of species of <a href="/wiki/Pinniped" title="Pinniped">seals</a> and <a href="/wiki/Whale" title="Whale">whales</a> along the coast.
</p><p>Over 100 species of birds have been seen, and around 50 breed in Greenland.
</p><p>There are very occasionally low forest of <a href="/wiki/Birch" title="Birch">birch</a> or <a href="/wiki/Willow" title="Willow">willow</a> and, in all, around 500 plant species.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ittoqqortoormiit_top_hg.jpg" title="File:Ittoqqortoormiit top hg.jpg">File:Ittoqqortoormiit top hg.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Colourful houses dot the town of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ittoqqortoormiit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ittoqqortoormiit (page does not exist)">Ittoqqortoormiit</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Qinngorput-Nuuk.JPG" title="File:Qinngorput-Nuuk.JPG">File:Qinngorput-Nuuk.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Urbanization in <a href="/wiki/Nuuk" title="Nuuk">Nuuk</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Greenland today is dependent on fishing and fish exports. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shrimp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shrimp (page does not exist)">shrimp</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fish&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fish (page does not exist)">fish</a> industry is by far the largest income earner.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup> Despite resumption<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:When&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:When (page does not exist)">Template:When</a> of several <a href="/wiki/Hydrocarbon" title="Hydrocarbon">hydrocarbon</a> and mineral exploration activities, it will take several years before hydrocarbon production can materialize. The state oil company <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nunaoil&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nunaoil (page does not exist)">Nunaoil</a> was created to help develop the hydrocarbon industry in Greenland. The state company Nunamineral has been launched on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Stock_Exchange&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Stock Exchange (page does not exist)">Copenhagen Stock Exchange</a> to raise more capital to increase the production of gold, started in 2007.
</p><p>Mining of <a href="/wiki/Ruby" title="Ruby">ruby</a> deposits began in 2007. Other mineral prospects are improving as prices are increasing. These include iron, <a href="/wiki/Uranium" title="Uranium">uranium</a>, aluminium, nickel, <a href="/wiki/Platinum" title="Platinum">platinum</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tungsten" title="Tungsten">tungsten</a>, <a href="/wiki/Titanium" title="Titanium">titanium</a>, and copper.
</p><p>Electricity has traditionally been generated by oil or diesel power plants, even if there is a large surplus of potential <a href="/wiki/Hydropower" title="Hydropower">hydropower</a>. Because of rising oil prices, there is a programme to build hydro power plants. The first, and still the largest, is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Buksefjord_hydroelectric_power_plant&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Buksefjord hydroelectric power plant (page does not exist)">Buksefjord hydroelectric power plant</a>.
</p><p>There are also plans to build a large aluminium smelter, using hydropower to create an exportable product. It is expected that much of the labour needed will be imported.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> has urged the Denmark protectorate Greenland to restrict People's Republic of China development of <a href="/wiki/Rare_earth_element" title="Rare earth element">rare-earth</a> projects, as China accounts for 95 percent of the world's current supply. In early 2013, the Greenland government said that it had no plans to impose such restrictions.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup>
</p><p>The public sector, including publicly owned enterprises and the municipalities, plays a dominant role in Greenland's economy. About half the government revenues come from grants from the Danish government, an important supplement to the gross domestic product (GDP). Gross domestic product per capita is equivalent to that of the average economies of Europe.
</p><p>Greenland suffered an economic contraction in the early 1990s. But, since 1993, the economy has improved. The Greenland Home Rule Government (GHRG) has pursued a tight fiscal policy since the late 1980s, which has helped create surpluses in the public budget and low inflation. Since 1990, Greenland has registered a foreign trade deficit following the closure of the last remaining lead and <a href="/wiki/Zinc" title="Zinc">zinc</a> mine that year. More recently,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:When&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:When (page does not exist)">Template:When</a> new sources of <a href="/wiki/Ruby" title="Ruby">ruby</a> in Greenland have been discovered, promising to bring new industry and a new export to the country. (See <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gemstone_industry_in_Greenland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gemstone industry in Greenland (page does not exist)">Gemstone industry in Greenland</a>).
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">Transportation</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Air_Greenland_Airbus_A330-Kangerlussuaq.jpg" title="File:Air Greenland Airbus A330-Kangerlussuaq.jpg">File:Air Greenland Airbus A330-Kangerlussuaq.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Air Greenland Airbus A330 at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kangerlussuaq_Airport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kangerlussuaq Airport (page does not exist)">Kangerlussuaq Airport</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Qaarsut-airport-air-greenland-bell212-dash7.jpg" title="File:Qaarsut-airport-air-greenland-bell212-dash7.jpg">File:Qaarsut-airport-air-greenland-bell212-dash7.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Helicopter and Dash-7 aircraft at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Qaarsut_Airport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Qaarsut Airport (page does not exist)">Qaarsut Airport</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Arctic-umiaq-sarfak-ittuk-narsaq.jpg" title="File:Arctic-umiaq-sarfak-ittuk-narsaq.jpg">File:Arctic-umiaq-sarfak-ittuk-narsaq.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The Sarfaq Ittuk, which belongs to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Arctic_Umiaq_Line&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Arctic Umiaq Line (page does not exist)">Arctic Umiaq Line</a></div></div></div>
<p>Air transportation exists both within Greenland and between the island and other nations. There is also scheduled boat traffic, but the long distances lead to long travel times and low frequency. There are no roads between cities because the coast has many fjords that would require ferry service to connect a road network,{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} Also the lack of agriculture, forestry and similar countryside activities has meant that very few countryside roads have been built.
</p><p>All civil aviation matters are handled by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Civil_Aviation_Administration_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Civil Aviation Administration Denmark (page does not exist)">Civil Aviation Administration Denmark</a>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kangerlussuaq_Airport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kangerlussuaq Airport (page does not exist)">Kangerlussuaq Airport</a> around 100&#160;km (60 miles) from the west coast is the major airport of Greenland and the hub for domestic flights. Intercontinental flights connect mainly to <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen" title="Copenhagen">Copenhagen</a>.
</p><p>In May 2007, <a href="/wiki/Air_Greenland" title="Air Greenland">Air Greenland</a> initiated a seasonal route to and from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Baltimore&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baltimore (page does not exist)">Baltimore</a> in the United States,<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> but on 10 March 2008, the route was cancelled because of financial losses.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> In 2012, Air Greenland commenced seasonal, biweekly flights between Nuuk and <a href="/wiki/Iqaluit" title="Iqaluit">Iqaluit</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup> Working in tandem with <a href="/wiki/First_Air" title="First Air">First Air</a> passengers can then continue to <a href="/wiki/Ottawa" title="Ottawa">Ottawa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Air_Iceland" title="Air Iceland">Air Iceland</a> began operating a twice-weekly <a href="/wiki/Keflav%C3%ADk_International_Airport" title="Keflavík International Airport">Keflavík</a>-<a href="/wiki/Ilulissat" title="Ilulissat">Ilulissat</a> route in July 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup> In addition to these routes there are scheduled international flights between <a href="/wiki/Narsarsuaq" title="Narsarsuaq">Narsarsuaq</a> and Copenhagen. Air Iceland operates routes between <a href="/w/index.php?title=Reykjav%C3%ADk_Airport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Reykjavík Airport (page does not exist)">Reykjavík</a> and Narsarsuaq, Ilulissat, Nuuk on the west coast and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kulusuk&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kulusuk (page does not exist)">Kulusuk</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ittoqqortoormiit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ittoqqortoormiit (page does not exist)">Ittoqqortoormiit</a> on the east coast.
</p><p>Sea <a href="/w/index.php?title=Passenger&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Passenger (page does not exist)">passenger</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cargo" title="Cargo">freight</a> transport is served by the coastal ferries operated by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Arctic_Umiaq_Line&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Arctic Umiaq Line (page does not exist)">Arctic Umiaq Line</a>. It makes a single round trip per week, taking 80 hours each direction.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Greenland has a population of 56,370 (January 2013 estimate),<sup id="cite_ref-Greenland_in_Figures_2013_3-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Greenland_in_Figures_2013-3">[3]</a></sup> of whom 88% are <a href="/wiki/Kalaallit" title="Kalaallit">Greenlandic Inuit</a> (including Inuit-<a href="/wiki/Danes" title="Danes">Danish</a> mixed). The remaining 12% are of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ethnic_groups_in_Europe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ethnic groups in Europe (page does not exist)">European</a> descent, mainly Danish. The majority of the population is <a href="/wiki/Church_of_Denmark" title="Church of Denmark">Lutheran</a>. Nearly all Greenlanders live along the fjords in the south-west of the main island, which has a relatively mild climate.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup> Over 16,000 people reside in Nuuk, the capital city.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Largest_cities_of_Greenland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Largest cities of Greenland (page does not exist)">Template:Largest cities of Greenland</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Nanortalik_church.jpg" title="File:Nanortalik church.jpg">File:Nanortalik church.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Most Greenlandic villages, including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nanortalik&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nanortalik (page does not exist)">Nanortalik</a>, have their own church.</div></div></div>
<p>The nomadic <a href="/w/index.php?title=Inuit_people&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Inuit people (page does not exist)">Inuit people</a> were traditionally <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shamanism_among_Eskimo_peoples&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shamanism among Eskimo peoples (page does not exist)">shamanistic</a>, with a well-developed <a href="/wiki/Inuit_mythology" title="Inuit mythology">mythology</a> primarily concerned with propitiating a vengeful and <a href="/wiki/Sedna_(mythology)" title="Sedna (mythology)">fingerless sea goddess</a> who controlled the success of the <a href="/wiki/Seal_hunting" title="Seal hunting">seal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Whaling" title="Whaling">whale hunts</a>.
