</p><p>The first <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norse_colonization_of_Greenland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Norse colonization of Greenland (page does not exist)">Norse colonists</a> were <a href="/wiki/Norse_religion" title="Norse religion">pagan</a>, but <a href="/wiki/Erik_the_Red" title="Erik the Red">Erik the Red</a>'s son <a href="/wiki/Leif_Ericson" title="Leif Ericson">Leif</a> was converted to Catholic Christianity by <a href="/wiki/List_of_Norwegian_monarchs" title="List of Norwegian monarchs">King</a> <a href="/wiki/Olaf_Trygvesson" title="Olaf Trygvesson" class="mw-redirect">Olaf Trygvesson</a> on a trip to Norway in 990 and sent missionaries back to Greenland. These swiftly established sixteen parishes, some monasteries, and a bishopric at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gar%C3%B0ar,_Greenland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Garðar, Greenland (page does not exist)">Garðar</a>.
</p><p>Rediscovering these colonists and spreading the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_Reformation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish Reformation (page does not exist)">Protestant Reformation</a> among them was one of the primary reasons for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_colonization_of_Greenland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish colonization of Greenland (page does not exist)">Danish recolonization</a> in the 18th century. Under the patronage of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Royal_Mission_College&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Royal Mission College (page does not exist)">Royal Mission College</a> in Copenhagen, Norwegian and Danish <a href="/wiki/Church_of_Denmark" title="Church of Denmark">Lutherans</a> and German <a href="/w/index.php?title=Moravian_missions_in_Greenland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Moravian missions in Greenland (page does not exist)">Moravian missionaries</a> searched for the missing Norse settlements and began converting the Inuit. The principal figures in the <a href="/wiki/Christianization" title="Christianization">Christianization</a> of Greenland were <a href="/wiki/Hans_Egede" title="Hans Egede">Hans</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Poul_Egede&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Poul Egede (page does not exist)">Poul Egede</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Matthias_Stach&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Matthias Stach (page does not exist)">Matthias Stach</a>. The <a href="/wiki/New_Testament" title="New Testament">New Testament</a> was translated piecemeal from the time of the very first settlement on Kangeq Island, but the first translation of the whole Bible was not completed until 1900. An improved translation using the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kalaallisut_orthography&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kalaallisut orthography (page does not exist)">modern orthography</a> was completed in 2000.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup>
</p><p>Today, the major religion is <a href="/wiki/Protestant_Christianity" title="Protestant Christianity" class="mw-redirect">Protestant Christianity</a>, mostly members of the Lutheran <a href="/wiki/Church_of_Denmark" title="Church of Denmark">Church of Denmark</a>. While there is no official census data on religion in Greenland, the Lutheran <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bishop_of_Greenland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bishop of Greenland (page does not exist)">Bishop of Greenland</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sofie_Petersen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sofie Petersen (page does not exist)">Sofie Petersen</a><sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> estimates that 85% of the Greenlandic population are members of her congregation.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> There are still Christian missionaries on the island, but mainly from <a href="/wiki/Charismatic_Christianity" title="Charismatic Christianity">charismatic movements</a> proselytizing fellow Christians.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} The first reported Muslim in Greenland, Wassam Azaqeer, made headlines around the world when he observed <a href="/wiki/Ramadan" title="Ramadan">Ramadan</a> in Nuuk, requiring him to fast for 21 hours at a time.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Parkverbot_Gr%C3%B6nland.jpg" title="File:Parkverbot Grönland.jpg">File:Parkverbot Grönland.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A bilingual sign in Nuuk, displaying the Danish and Kalaallisut for "Parking forbidden for all vehicles".</div></div></div>
<p>Both <a href="/wiki/Greenlandic_language" title="Greenlandic language">Greenlandic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Danish_language" title="Danish language">Danish</a> have been used in public affairs since the establishment of home rule in 1979; the majority of the population can speak both languages. Kalaallisut became the sole official language in June 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> In practice, Danish is still widely used in the administration and in higher education, as well as remaining the first or only language for some people in Nuuk and the larger towns. A debate about the role of Kalaallisut and Danish in future society is ongoing. The orthography of Kalaallisut was established already in 1851<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kalaallisut_orthography&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kalaallisut orthography (page does not exist)">revised</a> in 1973, and the country has a 100% literacy rate.<sup id="cite_ref-cia-factbook_77-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-factbook-77">[77]</a></sup>
</p><p>A majority of the population speaks Kalaallisut (West Greenlandic), most of them bilingually. It is spoken by about 50,000 people, making it the most populous of the <a href="/wiki/Eskimo%E2%80%93Aleut_languages" title="Eskimo–Aleut languages">Eskimo–Aleut</a> language family, spoken by more people than all the other languages of the family combined.
</p><p>Kalaallisut is the <a href="/wiki/Inuit_languages" title="Inuit languages">Inuit</a> dialect of West Greenland, which has long been the most populous area of the island. This has led to its de&#160;facto status as the official "Greenlandic" language, although the northern dialect <a href="/w/index.php?title=Inuktun_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Inuktun language (page does not exist)">Inuktun</a> remains spoken by 1,000 or so people around <a href="/wiki/Qaanaaq" title="Qaanaaq">Qaanaaq</a> and the eastern dialect <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tunumiit_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tunumiit language (page does not exist)">Tunumiisut</a> by around 3000.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup> These dialects are almost unintelligible to one another and are considered by some linguists to be separate languages.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} A <a href="/w/index.php?title=UNESCO&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UNESCO (page does not exist)">UNESCO</a> report has labelled the other dialects as endangered and measures are now being considered to protect the Eastern Greenlandic dialect.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Eskimo_Family_NGM-v31-p564.jpg" title="File:Eskimo Family NGM-v31-p564.jpg">File:Eskimo Family NGM-v31-p564.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">An <a href="/w/index.php?title=Inuit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Inuit (page does not exist)">Inuit</a> family in Greenland, 1917.</div></div></div>
<p>About 12% of the population speak Danish as their first or only language, many of them filling positions as administrators, professionals, academics, or skilled tradesmen. While Kalaallisut is dominant in smaller settlements, a part of the population of Inuit or mixed ancestry, especially in towns, speaks Danish as their first language. Most of the Inuit population speak Danish as second language. In larger towns, especially Nuuk and in the higher social strata, this is a large group. While one strategy aims at promoting Greenlandic in public life and education, developing its vocabulary and suitability for complex contexts, this approach is labelled "Greenlandization" by opponents who do not wish to aim at Greenlandic becoming the sole national language.
</p><p>English is taught in schools.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Upernavik_first_day_in_class_2007-08-14_2.jpg" title="File:Upernavik first day in class 2007-08-14 2.jpg">File:Upernavik first day in class 2007-08-14 2.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">School children in <a href="/wiki/Upernavik" title="Upernavik">Upernavik</a> start their first day of school wearing traditional Greenlandic costumes</div></div></div>
<p>Greenland's culture began with settlement in the second millennium BC by the <a href="/wiki/Dorset_culture" title="Dorset culture">Dorset Inuit</a>, shortly after the end of the ice age.
</p><p>In the 10th century, Icelandic and Norwegian Vikings settled in the southern part of the island, while the <a href="/wiki/Thule" title="Thule">Thule</a> Inuit culture was introduced in the north of the island and expanded southward. The culture clash between two peoples is attested by the discovery of a fragment of Viking chain mail at a high latitude of the island, while a figurine carved from walrus ivory, clearly of Inuit origin, was found in Bergen, Norway. Both objects must be understood as a clear testimony of the trade between the two peoples.
</p><p>Inuit culture dominated the island from the end of the Middle Ages to the recolonization in the early 18th century, where European culture was reintroduced.
</p><p>Today Greenlandic culture is a blending of traditional Inuit (<a href="/wiki/Kalaallit" title="Kalaallit">Kalaallit</a>) and Scandinavian culture. Inuit, or Kalaallit, culture has a strong artistic tradition, dating back thousands of years. The Kalaallit are known for an art form of figures called <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tupilak&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tupilak (page does not exist)">tupilak</a></i> or a "spirit object." Traditional art-making practices thrive in the <i>Ammassalik</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-ingo20_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ingo20-81">[81]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sperm_whale" title="Sperm whale">Sperm whale</a> ivory remains a valued medium for carving.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup>
</p><p>Greenland also has a successful, albeit small, music culture. Some popular <a href="/wiki/Greenlandic_language" title="Greenlandic language">Greenlandic</a> bands and artists include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sume_(band)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sume (band) (page does not exist)">Sume</a> (classic rock), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chilly_Friday&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chilly Friday (page does not exist)">Chilly Friday</a> (rock), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Siissisoq&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Siissisoq (page does not exist)">Siissisoq</a> (rock), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuuk_Posse&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuuk Posse (page does not exist)">Nuuk Posse</a> (hip hop) and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rasmus_Lyberth&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rasmus Lyberth (page does not exist)">Rasmus Lyberth</a> (folk), who performed in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Denmark_in_the_Eurovision_Song_Contest_1979&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Denmark in the Eurovision Song Contest 1979 (page does not exist)">Danish Eurovision Song Contest 1979</a>, performing in Greenlandic. The singer-songwriter <a href="/w/index.php?title=Simon_Lynge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Simon Lynge (page does not exist)">Simon Lynge</a> is the first musical artist from Greenland to have an album released across the United Kingdom, and to perform at the UK's <a href="/wiki/Glastonbury_Festival" title="Glastonbury Festival">Glastonbury Festival</a>. The music culture of Greenland also includes traditional <a href="/wiki/Inuit_music" title="Inuit music">Inuit music</a>, largely based around singing and drums.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Uummannaq-football-game.jpg" title="File:Uummannaq-football-game.jpg">File:Uummannaq-football-game.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Soccer match in <a href="/wiki/Uummannaq" title="Uummannaq">Uummannaq</a></div></div></div>
<p>Association football is the national sport of Greenland. The governing body, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Football_Association_of_Greenland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Football Association of Greenland (page does not exist)">Football Association of Greenland</a> (<i>Kalaallit Nunaanni Arsaattartut Kattuffiat</i>), is not yet a member of <a href="/wiki/FIFA" title="FIFA">FIFA</a> because of ongoing disagreements with <a href="/wiki/Sepp_Blatter" title="Sepp Blatter">Sepp Blatter</a> and an inability to grow grass for regulation grass pitches.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} However, it is the 17th member of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=N.F.-Board&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="N.F.-Board (page does not exist)">N.F.-Board</a>.
</p><p>In January 2007, Greenland took part in the <a href="/wiki/World_Men%27s_Handball_Championship" title="World Men's Handball Championship" class="mw-redirect">World Men's Handball Championship</a> in Germany, finishing 22nd in a field of 24 national teams.
</p><p>Greenland competes in the biennial <a href="/wiki/International_Island_Games_Association" title="International Island Games Association">Island Games</a>, as well as the biennial <a href="/wiki/Arctic_Winter_Games" title="Arctic Winter Games">Arctic Winter Games</a>. In 2002, Nuuk hosted the AWG in conjunction with <a href="/wiki/Iqaluit" title="Iqaluit">Iqaluit</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nunavut&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nunavut (page does not exist)">Nunavut</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup> Also in 2002 and previously in 1994 they won the <a href="/wiki/Stuart_Milton_Hodgson" title="Stuart Milton Hodgson">Hodgson Trophy</a> for fair play.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>

</p>
<ul>

<li><a href="/wiki/Telecommunications_in_Greenland" title="Telecommunications in Greenland">Telecommunications in Greenland</a>

<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Mountain_peaks_of_Greenland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mountain peaks of Greenland (page does not exist)">Mountain peaks of Greenland</a>
<ul>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_mountains_in_Greenland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of mountains in Greenland (page does not exist)">List of mountains in Greenland</a>
<ul>

</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Bibliography">Bibliography</span></h2>
<ul>
<li> Hessel, Ingo. <i>Arctic Spirit.</i> Vancouver: Douglas and McIntyre, 2006 <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9781553651895" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 978-1-55365-189-5</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cite_book&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cite book (page does not exist)">Template:Cite book</a>
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>
<ul>
<li> Bardarson, I. (ed. Jónsson, F.) "Det gamle Grønlands beskrivelse af Ívar Bárðarson (Ivar Bårdssön)", (Copenhagen, 1930).
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/CIA_World_Factbook" title="CIA World Factbook" class="mw-redirect">CIA World Factbook</a>, 2000.
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philip_Wheeler_Conkling&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philip Wheeler Conkling (page does not exist)">Conkling, P. W.</a> <i>et al.</i> 2011. The Fate of Greenland: Lessons from Abrupt Climate Change, co-authored with Richard Alley, Wallace Broecker and George Denton, with photographs by Gary Comer, MIT Press, Cambridge, MA.
</li>
<li> Lund, S. 1959. The Marine Algae of East Greenland. 1. Taxonomical Part. <i>Meddr Gronland.</i> 156(1), pp.&#160;1–245.
</li>
<li> Lund, S. 1959. The Marine Algae of East Greenland. 11. Geographic Distribution. <i>Meddr Gronland.</i> 156, pp.&#160;1–70.
</li>
<li> Steffen, Konrad, N. Cullen, and R. Huff (2005). "Climate variability and trends along the western slope of the Greenland Ice Sheet during 1991–2004," <i>Proceedings of the 85th American Meteorological Society Annual Meeting</i> (San Diego).
</li>
</ul>

											<li id="footer-places-privacy"><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia_clone:Privacy_policy" title="Wikipedia clone:Privacy policy">Privacy policy</a></li>
											<li id="footer-places-about"><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia_clone:About" title="Wikipedia clone:About">About Wikipedia</a></li>
											<li id="footer-places-disclaimer"><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_disclaimer" title="wikipedia:General disclaimer">Disclaimers</a></li>
									</ul>
										<ul id="footer-icons" class="noprint">
					<li id="footer-poweredbyico">
						<a href="//www.mediawiki.org/"><img src="/w/skins/common/images/poweredby_mediawiki_88x31.png" alt="Powered by MediaWiki" width="88" height="31" /></a>
					</li>
				</ul>
						<div style="clear:both"></div>
		</div>

}</script>
